text.p: Following are the leading stories in Pakistani newspapers on Sunday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The provincial government of Sindh has announced a 5.4 billion rupee cut in its development and non-development expenditure.
- The Supreme Court of Pakistan has returned the modified petition of Benazir Bhutto challenging the dissolution of the National Assembly and dismissal of her government.
- The Sindh High Court has ordered the state-run Karachi Water and Sewerage Board to pay compensation of 500,000 rupees to the parents of a child who died after he fell into an uncovered manhole.

- The caretaker government has decided to observe Pakistan's 50th anniversary celebrations in a simple manner and asked civil and military organisations to return all funds received earlier for this purpose.

- Caretaker Information Minister Irshad Haqqani said Pakistan did not need an official news agency and private television and radio stations should be allowed to compete with their state-run counterparts.
- The Sindh High Court has directed police to register cases against 33 people, including Asif Zardari, husband of ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto, on charges of robbery.
- Ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto charged that her government was dismissed to impose an IMF agenda on Pakistan.

- The caretaker government has decided to remove a five percent customs duty on import of raw cotton and reduced witholding tax on it to one percent from five percent as part of a package to help the spinning industry.
- The personal intervention of President Farooq Leghari has brought the $1.15 billion joint venture Iran-Pak oil refinery project back on track, sources said.
- The ban on imports of textile machinery, equipment and accessories from India has forced the textile industry to buy such items from Europe at prices five to 10 times higher, industry sources said.
